Grace and peace from the Lord. Such was the joy your letters brought me that they even made me shed tears while reading them. For they increased the opinion of your death with a disaster, as we read, near Capella (a place you somehow know from your writings), then the surrender of your hometown, and also that your brother Jacob had been seen in Cologne without speaking to me or bringing your writings that I always found so pleasant in the usual manner.
And so I was convinced that you had taken away half of my life with your premature death. I was asked about this by our hero and other people who had once known you very well, and I could not think of anything else but that you had been killed for the reasons mentioned.
When they hear that you are still alive, they congratulate you with all their heart.
Whenever the conversation turns to your disaster, I used to say that among those killed there were undoubtedly some who, if it were possible, would certainly be desired to be redeemed and brought back to life for a large sum.
I also read, for that reason, more attentively than ever, Zwingli's entire commentary on true and false religion, along with some of your compositions, with the greatest sorrow, that such a great patron had been so miserably slain to the great misfortune of all who live piously in Christ.

seg.output: Your letters filled me with such joy that they even provoked tears in me while I was reading them. For before their arrival, the news of your death had been increased by the disaster, as we read, that had taken place near Capella (a place known to you from your writings in some way). Then the surrender of your birthplace added to it, as well as the fact that your brother Jacob was said to have been seen in Cologne without speaking to me and without bringing me your always welcome letters in the usual way. Therefore, I was convinced that almost half of my soul had been taken away from me prematurely by your death. When asked about this by our hero and some of your once very familiar people, I replied that I could not suspect anything other than that you had been killed together for certain reasons. Now that they hear that you are still alive, they congratulate you fervently. Before that, whenever the talk happened to turn to your disaster, I used to say mostly that men had been taken away from that fight who could, if it were possible, certainly be wished for in the future and be bought back to life with a great sum of money. I read for this reason so diligently Zuingli's commentary on the true and false religion, with some of your studies, with great sorrow that such a great patron had been so miserably killed, the greatest of all evils for those who wanted to live piously in Christ. You can guess from this how unexpectedly, although gratefully, your letters were to me. With these, you not only filled me with solid joy for your safety and health, but you also, so to speak, painted with a brush the disaster and fight of your people. Such letters I showed and gave to be read to many learned men.

By them not only was I filled with solid joy at your safety and intactness, but you even depicted, as with a pencil, the disaster and fight of yours. I showed and gave these letters to be read by many learned men. To some of them I even related in order the occasion, progress and end of the battle, together with the number of the slain. And I admire today what presage was meant by that man, whom you remember, who was always going around among us with his tales about Swiss history, and was always suspect of telling lies.

And I am amazed today by which premonition that one, whom you remember, who had been circulated around us with a false account of the Swiss history, had been always suspected of lying. Yet, I think, the messenger tries to approve it with flattering words, lured by the dainties of the rich sacrificers. Yet, for this, I believe, he was punished in Strasbourg with three days in jail.

When they now hear that you are still alive, they heartily congratulate me. Before this, whenever the topic of your tragedy came up, I would mostly say that such great people, if possible, could be redeemed and brought back to life by an immense sum of money. I read this not only with the greatest attention, but also with great sorrow, that a patron so great should be so miserably slaughtered, to the great misfortune of all who live piously in Christ. From this you can understand how unexpectedly – although gladly – your letters were for me. Not only did they fill me with solid joy for your safety and health, but also, in a certain way, you depicted the tragedy and battle of your people as if with a brush. I showed these letters to many educated people and gave them to read. I also recounted to some of them the cause, the course, and the end of the battle, with the number of the dead. I am amazed today at the prophecy of the man you remember, who had always circulated around us with his tale of the history of the Swiss, and was always suspected of exaggeration. However, he is trying to confirm his story with persuasive words, I believe, by being lured by offerings from influential people. Nevertheless, he was punished in Strasbourg for this, I believe, by being imprisoned for three days. He can tell you the cause. Perhaps it won't seem right that he maintains more thousands were killed than you report were dozens. However, I have always had and will have more faith in you, even if you don't assure me that I can tell your story as if it were the gospel of God. Furthermore, how could eight thousand be forced away from the mountains by six hundred, even by ambush, and many other things, the places and people being almost unknown, which I cannot list? Nevertheless, as much as I could, I objected to those things which didn't seem very probable, even more confidently, because a different opportunity and convenience had been offered to me to send letters to you, my most friendly man. For, from the recent Frankfurt Fair, I had also received your letters with two of your works, which I see are now being published in Cologne, something that never happened with the others.

seg.output: I was so filled with joy at your letter that it even provoked tears in me as I read it. For before its arrival, the reports of your death had increased the grief with the calamity, as we read, that had taken place near Capella (a place known to you from your writings), and moreover, because Jacob, your brother, was seen in Cologne and had not talked to me, nor had your usually much-appreciated letters been brought as was customary. Thus I was overcome by the thought that half of my soul had been taken away from me prematurely by death. When questioned about this by our hero and other friends of yours I had known, I said that I could not suspect anything else than that you had been killed at the same time, for certain reasons. Now when they hear that you are still alive, they all congratulate you earnestly. I had already, whenever the conversation touched on the destruction of your party, often mentioned that such people had been taken away, who, if it were possible, would certainly be redeemed at a great price and brought back to life. I read the reason for this so that I never read with more attention Zwingli's book on true and false religion, together with some of your writings, not without great sorrow, that such a patron had so miserably been slain, to the great misfortune of all who live piously in Christ. You can conclude from this how unexpectedly, though thankfully, my joy was great when I received your letter. Not only did it fill me with solid joy at your safety and health, but also with a certain graphic description of the destruction and battle of your party as if painted with a brush. I showed these letters to many scholars and gave them to read. I also recounted to certain ones in order, the occasion, development and end of the battle with the number of the slain. I am amazed today at the foresight of that man whose name you remember, who was always circulating around us with his story of the Swiss history, which was always suspected to be untrue. But he tries to approve it with persuasive words, I believe, because he had been seduced by the tempting gifts of the priests. Nevertheless, he has paid his penalty at Strasbourg, I believe, for having been imprisoned for three days. He will tell you the reason. Perhaps it will seem strange to him that you report less than eight thousands having been killed, while he claims more than sixty thousand. But I have always had and will have more faith in you, even if you do not assure me that I can relate your news as gospel truth. Moreover, how could it be that in the mountains, though by ambush, six thousand could drive off eight thousand and innumerable others? Which, since I cannot enumerate the places and nations almost unknown, I could not do. But he himself describes the lamentable affair almost, and to one who has little hope left, he embellishes it with false words, but always adding that you are a good and honest man, who takes a middle course and does not favour too much either side. However, I tried to refute those things which did not seem likely, as much as I could, with even more confidence, because another opportunity and opportunity to send letters to you, a very friendly man to me, had been offered. For from the near Frankfurt markets your letters have also come to me, with two of your books; which indeed I later saw publicly being sold at Cologne, which has never been the case with the others. For these I offer you unfading thanks and pray for the saying: "Be brave, my son, thus you will go to the stars". And our hero will be charged with the task of reading your speech on the prophetic function according to your orders. Furthermore, the little brother reported that a great amount of money had been taken away from the Baselers, that your party was held responsible for the loss inflicted on the enemies, and that I don't know how many thousand ducats were paid for sixteen buildings that had been burnt down [!], also how each city of your party blames the other for the opportunity and the cause of such great evil, and a now incredible discord between them, and also that you and your parents and brother were forced to leave your former homes and that they are now being hosted by you at Thurgau, and many other things, which I think it would be too tedious to enumerate. If this is so, I beg you not to forget your duty of piety towards your parents and relatives and to strive especially, as much as possible without offending God, for peace and unity.

seg.output: I was filled with such joy when I read your letter that it even made me cry. For before your letter arrived, I had heard of your death, as we had read of the defeat that had taken place near Capella (a place known to you from your writings), as well as the surrender of your birthplace, and also that your brother Jacob had been seen at Cologne without speaking to me and without bringing your beloved letters as he usually did. So I was convinced that my dearest half of my soul had been taken away from me prematurely. When I was asked about this by our hero and other people who had once been close to you, I could not think of anything else but that you had been killed for the reasons mentioned. Now when they hear that you are still alive, they congratulate you heartily. Also, whenever the conversation turns to your disaster, I often bring in the fact that such people were taken away who, if it was possible, would without doubt have been bought back with a large sum of money and brought back to life. I read for this reason with greater attention than ever before Zwingli’s commentary on true and false religion, accompanied by some of your writings, not without great sorrow, that such a great patron was so miserably killed, to the greatest grief of all who live piously in Christ. You can guess from this how unexpectedly, although gratefully, your letter was for me. This letter not only filled me with solid joy about your safety and well-being, but also painted the disaster and battle of your people with a kind of brush. I showed and gave these letters to many learned people to read. To some I even recounted the occasion, the course and the end of the battle, as well as the number of those killed. And I admire today the prescience of that man whose name you know, who had been carrying around with us a false report of Swiss history and was always suspected of lying. But a messenger seems to try to approve him with persuasive words, probably having been lured by the tasty dishes of the wealthy. He did pay the price in Strasbourg, and I think he was imprisoned there for three days. Let him tell you the reason. Perhaps he will not think it strange to say that many thousands were killed, while you report only a few hundred. But I have always had more faith in you than in anyone else, and will have, even if you do not assure me that I can report your words as certain truth like the gospel of God. Furthermore, how is it possible that with ambushes, eight thousand six hundred were driven away into the mountains and an innumerable number of other things which I cannot list, as I do not know the places and people involved, but which I have learned from your letter, to the best of my capacity and understanding. But he himself passed over the deplorable matter, and it is necessary to embellish with false words to one who has little hope left, always adding that you are an honest and sincere man, taking a middle way, not favouring either party too much. Nevertheless, I objected as much as I could to those things which did not seem very likely to me, and this with so much more confidence because of the other opportunity and opportunity to send letters to you, a very friendly man. For news from the recent Frankfurt Fair had also reached me, including your letter and two of your writings, which I now see publicly in Cologne, which did not happen with the others. For this I thank you immortal, praying “Macte virtute, puer, sic itur ad astra”. And a suitable opportunity will be sought for our hero to read your speech on the prophetic function at your request. Furthermore, my little brother reported that a great sum of money had been taken from Basel to compensate the damage done to the opponents, and that your people would have to pay a number of thousands of ducats for the sixteen houses burned down, and how each city of your party accuses the other of giving the occasion and cause for such a great evil, and the incredible discord among them, and that you were forced to leave your old home with your parents and brother, and that they are now staying as guests with you in Zurich, and many other things, all of which I find too tedious to list. If this is so, I beg you not to forget your parents and relatives in your piety and to strive especially, as much as possible without offending God, for peace and unity. For we believe that certain ceremonies can be endured more easily than hatred, resentment and discord.

seg.output: You ask, among other things, that I respond to these letters so that you feel I and my superiors have received them. I have responded to the superiors to whom you had sent the pamphlet against the Anabaptists, not knowing if I did so with the proper diligence. I also do not know if I responded to any of your letters according to your instructions, which, as the words show, accuse me of avarice. For you write after mentioning avarice, as follows: "Therefore you should keep your enemy recommended, so that you do not depart from him except punished." Although you thus allege me of this most abominable sin, yet by the grace of God I am conscious to myself of no such thing. For if ever I had studied gain, there had been long since a more convenient way offered me, which at present, being content with present things, I can hardly maintain myself with a few morsels of bread. So that I wish, for no other cause than the warmth of the gospel, to change my place, if it could be conveniently done. Nevertheless, we hope, God willing, the glory of the gospel will flourish and shortly. For already it begins to bud and flourish.

seg.output: In response to your request, I would like to let you know that I and my superiors have received your letter. I had already responded to the superiors you had sent the pamphlet against the Anabaptists, though I was unaware whether or not I had done so with the appropriate diligence. I am also unaware if I had not responded to any of your requests as you had accused me of being greedy. You wrote, following the mention of greed, "Therefore, you should keep your enemy in check, so that you may depart from him only with a wound". Although you may accuse me of that most abominable sin, I am not conscious of it by the grace of God. If I had ever strived for money, a much more convenient opportunity would have been presented to me before, but now I am content with merely having a small plate of food. Therefore, I wish to change my place, if it can be done suitably, due to the warmth of the gospel. However, with the divine grace, we hope that the glory of the gospel will flourish soon. Already it is sprouting. Many commoners and scholars secretly favor the gospel among us. But no one dares to openly criticize the vices and abuses due to the tyranny of the rulers. The Duke of Juliers also provided a certain specimen of piety, as you can see in his attached constitutions. Even our Bishop is harshly criticized by the priests and monks.

I have indeed responded to the superiors to whom you sent the book against the Anabaptists, although I am unaware of doing so with the appropriate diligence. For you write, after mentioning avarice: “So, have that enemy of yours recommended, so that you may depart from him with only a scar.” Although you thus accuse me of this most abominable sin, yet I am not conscious of it by the grace of God. I have already responded to my superiors who sent you a pamphlet against the Anabaptists, though I am not sure if I did so with the requisite diligence. seg.output: I have replied to your superiors, with whom you had sent a book against the Anabaptists, to the best of my ability. I am not sure if I have responded to all of your requests as you accuse me of being greedy. Nevertheless, I am not guilty of this abominable sin, for if I had ever desired money, there would have been a much easier way for me to obtain it than what I have now with the meager amount of food I can barely afford. So that, if it were not for the dissension, such as the one you have experienced, or the tyrants who enrage their subjects, Westphalia will soon accept the true gospel of God. But oh, if only they expressed it with their morals and innocent life (in your words).

seg.output: In response to your letter, I can assure you that my superiors and I have received it. I responded to those superiors to whom you sent the book against the Anabaptists, although I am unaware if I did so with due diligence. I am also unaware if I responded at all to your instructions, which you accuse me of in your words, attributing it to avarice. You write, following the mention of avarice, as follows: "Therefore, you must consider that enemy of yours recommended, so that you do not depart from him without a blow". Although you insinuate that I am guilty of this most abominable sin, I do not feel conscious of it before God. If I had ever been interested in money, it would have been shown to me a long time ago a much more convenient way to acquire it, which now, content with my present circumstances, I scarcely fill a small plate with groats. Therefore, what I mainly desire, more than anything else, is to change my place, if it could be done suitably, due to my great affection for the gospel. Nevertheless, with God willing, the glory of the gospel will flourish soon. For it is already sprouting. For many common people and learned persons among us secretly favour the gospel. But no one dares to openly blame the vices and abuses because of the tyranny of the rulers. The Duke of Juliers gave a certain example of his piety, as you can see in his constitutions. Even our bishop is badly heard by the sacrificers and monks. For he has abrogated, or rather freed, some solemnities of the saints, so that the poor would not be burdened with so many holidays, and so that the sins and crimes usually committed in those days would not be multiplied. Nor does he esteem highly the papistic bulls, thunderbolts and excommunications, with which he opposes himself by freely conferring ecclesiastical benefits to everyone, even in turns of the apostolic, as they say. For recently the Pope excommunicated the college of Saint Cunibert, because it refused to offer the testaments of the apostolic to the one who was asking for possession, according to the bishop's order, while the bishop absolved them. Although these things may seem ridiculous and absurd, as they are really insignificant, they are still intended to show something new. Recently Zusatum, a wealthy city of Westphalia, expelled the gross ones and admitted those who truly explain the Scriptures. The same is reported to have been attempted in Monasterii, another renowned city of Westphalia, and also in Lower Wesel and some other small towns, such as Lippia and Hammone, to such an extent that, if the devil had not caused the dissension, such as the one you had, or had not exasperated tyrants against their subjects, soon all of Westphalia would admit the true gospel of God. seg.output: I therefore answer your letter in such a way that you may feel that I and my superiors have received it. Indeed, I responded to the superiors to whom you had sent the pamphlet against the Anabaptists, not knowing whether I did so with the diligence which was required. I do not even know whether I have responded to any of your letters according to their instructions, as you accuse me in them of avarice. For you write, after mentioning avarice, as follows: "So you should treat that enemy of yours as recommended, so that you depart from him only beaten". Although thus you seem to accuse me of the most abominable sin, yet I am conscious of no guilt of it through the grace of God. For if ever I had studied for money, an easier way had long before been shown me, which I am now contented with, scarcely able to get a little dish of boiled potatoes. So that I wish nothing more than for a change of place, if it can be done conveniently, chiefly for the warmth of the gospel. But we hope that it will soon flourish through the Divine grace, if God will. For it is already sprouting; for many of the common people as well as the learned among us secretly favour the gospel. But none of them dares to break out openly against the vices and abuses; and the Duke of Juliers has given a sample of his piety, as you may see by his constitutions annexed. And our Bishop is also ill heard of by the sacrificers and monks; for he has abrogated or rather freed some of the solemnities of the saints, lest the poor should be oppressed by them, and lest the sins and wickedness then commonly practiced should be multiplied. Nor does he much regard the bulls, thunderings, and execrations of the Papists, with which he opposes them, freely conferring ecclesiastical benefits upon every one in order, as it is said. For the Pope lately excommunicated the College of St. Cunibert, because it would not present the Apostolical Te-Deums to him that claimed the possession by his command; but the Bishop absolved them. Though these things seem ridiculous and absurd, as indeed they are but trifles, yet they seem to portend something. Lately Zusatum, a wealthy city in Westphalia, has thrown off the grossest sort of men, and admitted such as truly expound the Scriptures. The same is reported to be attempted at Monasterii, another eminent city of Westphalia, and likewise in Lower Velsia, and some other small cities, as Lippia and Hammone; so that, unless the Devil stir up a division among us, as he has done among you, or tyrants provoke their subjects, Westphalia will shortly admit the true gospel of God. But oh, that all would express it by their behaviour and innocent lives (as you express it)! There are also some great men in the Duchy of Juliers, that admit the pure gospel, as the Count of Morsa; and some towns also; and hitherto, through the grace of God, it has spread without divisions or bloodshed. O that it would spread, in like manner, without scandal or offence to any, till we all with one mouth glorify our Father which is in Heaven.

seg.output:
Caesar gathered an immense treasure of money in Brabant in the year 32. For what use and to whose benefit will it be? He then departed with a large entourage to Cologne on the last days of March to attend the princes' assembly of Germany, and he is said to be expecting news there about the so-called Lutheran affair, for which the Emperor's delegation at Swinford in Eastern France, the Bishop of Mainz, the Count Palatine and some others are asking a response. However, as we have been reported from one of our consuls sent to Cologne, the assembly may be frustrated, because, as it is said, the princes of Germany do not want to obey Caesar in everything, who is striving with all his might to restore the Pope's authority. It is also said that Rome has been attacked once again by the Spanish and other mercenary soldiers for not paying the salary of the siege of Florence, and that they have inflicted great losses on the cardinals, and that the Pope himself barely escaped from their furious hands to the Castle of the Holy Angel, which they are now besieging with the permission of the Roman citizens, begging for this evil to be spared from them.
These are the things, my Henry, that I did not want to hide from you. Farewell, and tell my beloved to remember me and to greet all our common friends in my name.
Given in Cologne, on the 16th of April, in the year 32.
Theodericus Bitter Wipperford.

seg.output: I was so filled with joy by your letters, that when I read them, even tears were provoked. For before their arrival, the report of your death was increased with disaster, as it is written that a surrender had taken place in the place of your birth near Capella (a place known to you by your writings in some way), and also that your brother Jacob had been seen in Cologne without speaking to me, and without bringing the letters that I had always appreciated so much. So I complained repeatedly to those closest to me that you had taken away half of my soul prematurely. When asked about this by our hero and others who had once been very close to you, I replied that I could not suspect anything else but that you had been killed at the same time, for predetermined reasons. When they now hear that you are still alive and well, they congratulate you warmly. Even before, whenever the conversation turned to the disaster that had befallen you, I often brought up that those who had been taken away in that battle could, if it were possible, surely later be redeemed for a great sum of money and brought back to life. I read for this reason so diligently the whole of Zwingli's commentaries on true and false religion, with some of your labors, not without intense sorrow, that such a great patron had been so miserably cut down, to the greatest misfortune of all those who desired to live piously in Christ. You can guess from this how unexpectedly, though gratefully, your letters were to me. With them I filled not only me with solid joy for your safety and health, but also in some way painted the disaster and the battle of you with a brush, as it were. I showed and gave these letters to be read by many learned people. To some I even related in order the occasion, course, and end of the battle, with the number of those killed. And I wonder today with what foresight that one, whom you remember, who was always circulated among us as a false rumor of the history of the Swiss, was suspect. Nevertheless, it seems to me that the messenger tries to approve it with flattering words, lured by the bountiful feasts of the priests. seg.output: You ask, among other things, that I should reply to your letter in such a way that you will feel that I and my superiors have received it. To the former, with whom you had sent a book against the Anabaptists, I replied, not knowing whether I had done it with the diligence which was proper. I do not even know if I have not answered any of yours according to your plan, by charging me, as the words imply, with avarice. For you write, after mentioning avarice, as follows: "Therefore you should keep that enemy of yours in your favour, so that you may depart from him with nothing but a beating". Although you imply that I am guilty of this most abominable sin, nevertheless I am not conscious of it by the grace of God. For if I had ever been a lover of money, there had been shown to me long ago a far more convenient way, which now, being content with my present means, I can scarcely fill a little dish with a vegetable stew. So, that I may wish rather than anything else for a change of place, if it can be conveniently effected, on account of the warmth of the gospel. Nevertheless we hope, with the divine favour, that the glory of the gospel will flourish shortly. For it is now springing up. For many of the common people and the learned among us secretly favour the gospel. But no one dares to break out openly, and to reprehend publicly the vices and abuses. The Duke of Juliers has given some evidence of his piety, that you may see in the constitutions he has annexed. But even our Bishop is ill spoken of by the sacrificers and monks. For he has abrogated, or rather freed, some of the festivals of the saints, lest the poor should be burdened with so many feast days, and lest the sins and wickedness, which are usually committed then, should be multiplied. Nor does he make much of the papistical bulls, thunders and curses, with which he opposes himself, freely conferring ecclesiastical benefits on every one in his turn, even an apostolical one, as it is said. For lately the Pope has excommunicated the College of St. Cunibert, because it would not confer the apostolical bulls on him who offered possession by the Bishop's command; but the Bishop has absolved it. Though these things may seem ridiculous and absurd, as they are indeed minute, yet they show some new thing.

seg.output: I respond to your letter in such a way that you feel that I and my superiors have received it. I had already responded to the superiors with whom you had sent the pamphlet against the Anabaptists, without knowing if I had done so with the proper diligence. I also do not know if I have not answered any of your letters, as you accuse me of avarice in the same. For you write after mentioning avarice, as follows: "Therefore, take your enemy recommended by you, so that you do not leave him until you have punished him". Although you may accuse me of this most abominable sin, I am nevertheless not conscious of it by the grace of God. For if I had ever striven for money, there would have been a long time ago, a much more advantageous way shown to me, which, however, contented with the present, I can hardly support with a little dish. So, that I wish above all things to change my place if it could be done conveniently, for the warmth of the gospel. But we hope, with the divine grace, that the glory of the gospel shall flourish soon. For it is already sprouting; for many of the plebeians and learned among us secretly favour the gospel. But no one dares to break out openly and to reprehend the vices and abuses. The duke of Juliers gave a certain example of piety, as you may see in his constitutions annexed. Our bishop is also ill heard of by the sacrificers and monks. For he has abolished, or rather freed, certain festivals of the saints, that the poor might not be burdened with them on so many festive days, nor that the sins and wickedness usually then committed should be multiplied. Nor does he make much of the popish Bulls, thunders and execrations, to which he opposes freely conferring ecclesiastical benefits on every one in his turn, even apostolic, as is said. For lately the pope excommunicated the college of St. Cunibert, because it would not confer the apostolic letters to him that demanded the possession by the bishop's command. Although these things may seem ridiculous and absurd, as they are truly trifles, yet something is designed to portend somewhat new. Lately also Zusatum, a wealthy city of Westphalia, has thrown out the gross ones, and admitted those that truly explain the scriptures. The same is said to have been attempted at Monasterii, another renowned city of Westphalia, and likewise in Lower Velsalia, and some other little cities, as Lippia and Hammone, so that, unless the devil stirs up a dissension, such as has been with you, or tyrants irritate their subjects, the whole of Westphalia will shortly admit the true gospel of God. But O that they would express it by their morals and innocence of life (as you say!) So there are some great ones in the land of Juliers that admit the pure gospel; as the Count of Morsa, likewise some little towns, and hitherto, by the grace of God, without dissensions and calamities. Which may it please to spread abroad as far as without scandal and offence to any, until we all glorify with one mouth our Father who is in heaven. May he be pleased to grant it to us, who is blessed for ever. Amen. [Rom 1:25]

Caesar gathered an immense treasure of money in Brabant in the year exact. To what use will it be appropriated? He left for Cologne Ratisbon with a large retinue, a few days before the last day of Lent, in order to attend the meeting of the princes of Germany and to wait there for a message, as it is said, about the affair called Lutheran, for which the bishop of Schmalkalden, the Palatine count and some others ask an answer from the emperor Svinpford in Eastern France. But, as it is reported to us from a letter of one of our councillors sent to Ratisbon, which he gave to his wife, the meeting perhaps will be frustrated, for it is said that the princes of Germany would not obey in all things to Caesar, who strives with great effort to restore the insolence of the pope. It is also said that Rome was again attacked by the Spaniards and other mercenary soldiers for the non-payment of the pay of the siege of Florence, and that they inflicted great losses on the cardinals, and that the pope himself barely escaped the furious hands of them into the castle of St. Angel, which they now besiege, with the permission of the Roman citizens, and they implore this misfortune as if it were innocent.
These are, my Henry, the things that I did not want to hide from you. Farewell and command my beloved to greet all of our common friends in my name.
Given in Cologne, April 16th, in the year 32.
Theodericus Bitter Wipperford.
